Please help me...

item.title: Hi
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:24, topic:547916”][quote author=Lin link=topic=666821.msg4458665#msg4458665 date=1416331992]

C++ is the superior language.
[/quote]Bandwagoning at its finest. There is no “superior” language. You can have languages with the best flexibility, portability, simplicity, and “learnability”, but never speed. C++ would win in flexibility maybe because of all the code readily available, but fall short in portability to Java and maybe even .NET languages depending on the libraries used, and definitely in the simplicity and learnability departments. You have to learn all about memory management, how the compiler works, and so on to even write something decent. With Visual Basic for example, it’s the closest you’ll get to something like English and it takes little code to make something usable, and with the JIT compiler it can even outperform C++. The more you study programming, the more you learn a lot of C++ is just hype. With wrappers for popular libraries, and runtime optimizations not possible in C++, unless you’re very decent with C++ you’re actually better off learning something else.

TL;DR - C++ is bad compared to everything else out there.

Please fukoff with the JIT-can-be-potentially-faster talk. Have you seen this in practice yourself, got any performance comparisons to back it up or are you just forwarding the marketing bullshit around managed languages?

Also PHP is super shit. Use ASP.NET for web.[/quote]okay grandpa

Read full topic

item.description:

C++ is the superior language.

Rust is better than C++

Rust is gr8.!

Golang is btr

Java > Golang.

mmm

golang concurrency features are better (channels, goroutines),
easier to import modules,
typing is easier to manage,
has wider basic api

yeeeaaah.

Pretty slow too.
[/quote]

this is beyond the scope of your experience[/quote]
What can I say? I used it once, didn’t like it. It’s really not a good language imo.

item.title: Hi
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:8, topic:547916”]Or rather, what about which language you might want to avoid? I guess the “best” language is the one that is the least bad – you pick the reasons.

http://www.reddit.com/r/programming/wiki/faq#wiki_why_do_you_hate_.3Cinsert_language_that.27s_unpopular_on_proggit.3E.3F

[quote]Why do you hate <insert language that’s unpopular on proggit>?
NEEDS WORK

C++: Hating it is trendy. Actually just hate the fanboys who just learned it as their second language and think it’s the best thing ever. Ugly syntax. Badly bolted onto C. Horribly convoluted enterprise libraries that cling to every popular OO language. Segmentation Fault. Template error messages are useless and massive.

C: Function pointer syntax is cumbersome. Segmentation faults. Some of the library functions were designed by idiots.

Objective-C: Mac people like it. It’s still C.

Lisp: Not pure enough. Confusing naming conventions. Parenthesis. Not all library functions behave well with eachother.

Java: Syntax too big. Too slow. Everything has to be in a class. Swing sucks. Spring. Associated with horrible enterprise bloat, a la Kingdom of Nouns. No function pointers. Collection framework can’t handle conversion to collection of a supertype. Sometimes awt is hardware accelerated and sometimes it’s not. Float type is not compatible with anything.

Python: Whitespace is dumb. Slow. Line wrap syntax is dumb. Object orientation syntax is dumb. Scope syntax is dumb.

Haskell: Nobody understands it. Ugly syntax. Fanboys.

Ruby: Monkey patching. Traditionally slow VM. Broken version of Python with inconsistent semantics. Slow version of perl.

Perl: Ugly. Unreadable.

PHP: See r/lolphp.[/quote]

It tends to be pretty accurate. Also:

[quote]Which programming language should I learn?
C: You like low level stuff and you want to be pretty close to the metal. Some people call it portable, but it isn’t really that portable.
C++: Like C, but easier and klunkier, with object orientedness thrown in.
C#: Runs perfect on Windows. Runs great on Linux/Mac, but gets lots of hate because “Micro$oft’s” fingers are in it. Like Java, but not shitty.
Assembly: You will learn everything there is to know about your computer if you learn assembly.
HTML/CSS/JS: You don’t really want to be a programmer, you just want a website.
JS on its own: If you like low level, you’ll hate JavaScript. It’s pretty pleasant otherwise. Not much out-of-browser support yet.
PHP: Please, for the love of God, don’t even bother.
Python: Nice standard library, lightweight, easy to start new project. Whitespace is syntactically important.
Java: Runs on a lot of stuff, but has lots of boilerplate and forces you to arrange your source tree by namespace (I think).
brainfudge: Not practical for anything, but it’s fun to try for a while and forces you to think in new ways.[/quote]

Sincerely,
Whackatre
Certified Language Hopper[/quote]Hey! I’m a certified language hopper too!

Read full topic

item.title: Hi
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Or rather, what about which language you might want to avoid? I guess the “best” language is the one that is the least bad – you pick the reasons.

http://www.reddit.com/r/programming/wiki/faq#wiki_why_do_you_hate_.3Cinsert_language_that.27s_unpopular_on_proggit.3E.3F

Why do you hate ? NEEDS WORK

C++: Hating it is trendy. Actually just hate the fanboys who just learned it as their second language and think it’s the best thing ever. Ugly syntax. Badly bolted onto C. Horribly convoluted enterprise libraries that cling to every popular OO language. Segmentation Fault. Template error messages are useless and massive.

C: Function pointer syntax is cumbersome. Segmentation faults. Some of the library functions were designed by idiots.

Objective-C: Mac people like it. It’s still C.

Lisp: Not pure enough. Confusing naming conventions. Parenthesis. Not all library functions behave well with eachother.

Java: Syntax too big. Too slow. Everything has to be in a class. Swing sucks. Spring. Associated with horrible enterprise bloat, a la Kingdom of Nouns. No function pointers. Collection framework can’t handle conversion to collection of a supertype. Sometimes awt is hardware accelerated and sometimes it’s not. Float type is not compatible with anything.

Python: Whitespace is dumb. Slow. Line wrap syntax is dumb. Object orientation syntax is dumb. Scope syntax is dumb.

Haskell: Nobody understands it. Ugly syntax. Fanboys.

Ruby: Monkey patching. Traditionally slow VM. Broken version of Python with inconsistent semantics. Slow version of perl.

Perl: Ugly. Unreadable.

PHP: See r/lolphp.

It tends to be pretty accurate. Also:

Which programming language should I learn? C: You like low level stuff and you want to be pretty close to the metal. Some people call it portable, but it isn't really that portable. C++: Like C, but easier and klunkier, with object orientedness thrown in. C#: Runs perfect on Windows. Runs great on Linux/Mac, but gets lots of hate because "Micro$oft's" fingers are in it. Like Java, but not shitty. Assembly: You will learn everything there is to know about your computer if you learn assembly. HTML/CSS/JS: You don't really want to be a programmer, you just want a website. JS on its own: If you like low level, you'll hate JavaScript. It's pretty pleasant otherwise. Not much out-of-browser support yet. PHP: Please, for the love of God, don't even bother. Python: Nice standard library, lightweight, easy to start new project. Whitespace is syntactically important. Java: Runs on a lot of stuff, but has lots of boilerplate and forces you to arrange your source tree by namespace (I think). brainfudge: Not practical for anything, but it's fun to try for a while and forces you to think in new ways.

Sincerely,
Whackatre
Certified Language Hopper

Read full topic

item.title: Hi
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

LISP (or Common Lisp) for flexibility.

Malbolge, just because you can.

C because it’s a relatively low-level, yet great, language.

GLSL, the OpenGL Shading Language, to create shaders for OpenGL.

Java because it’s a great object-oriented language.

ASM (or NASM like I used), just because you can.

In my opinion, C++ is just a bloated language. I preferrably wouldn’t use it. Although we have to do that at times at work. The same story about Delphi, which is even (much) worse.

Read full topic
